title: annegret kramp karrenbauer irish backstop
story: Unlikely because it does not yet exist and requires a sharp change of attitude on all sides.But in times of crisis, ­anything is possible.Hardline Tory Brexiteers are now prepared to vote for ­Theresa May’s shattered EU Withdrawal Bill — as long as she ditches the wretched Northern Ireland backstop.Meanwhile, Germany is under siege from its political and industrial leaders, who are finally speaking out against a breach in trade and security ties with a vital European ally.Together this makes it ­possible to navigate a way through the thicket of bitterness and rancour which has soured ­politics, ided families and split the British nation.It requires a change of tack from Theresa May — never an easy ask.The PM’s deal is toxic because it hands Northern ­Ireland to Brussels as a ­province of the EU.Cutting out this tumour would win Mrs May the backing of at least  MPs, including Tory Brexiteers and the hardline DUP.Remainers would have ­little choice but to join in, giving Mrs May her majority and scuppering Jeremy ­Corbyn’s demands for a snap election.This might be seen as an impossible dream, not least because the hated backstop was allegedly invented in Downing Street, not Brussels.German negotiators pounced on an easy win.Now Berlin, the ultimate EU power broker, is facing fierce protests from industrialists over the risk to car, aerospace and engineering giantsBritain leaves with No Deal.“A hard Brexit would be disastrous,” says Dieter Kempf, head of Germany’s BDI — the equivalent of our Confederation of British Industry.“It would cause great dficulty for tens of thousands of companies and hundreds of thousands of workers on both sides.”Friday’s touching note from German politicians to The Times newspaper pleads with Britain to stay — or at least leave on friendly terms.But this is no love letter. It is hard-nosed realism.Signicantly, it bears the ­signature of Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, Angela Merkel’s chosen successor as Germany’s next Chancellor.Her appeal can be seen as a rebuke to Mrs Merkel, who rejected David Cameron’s plea for help to curb immigration, tipping ­Britain towards Brexit.Brits might have chosen dferentlyshe had responded to voters’ dismay not just in Britain but across the EU.She later signed her own political death warrant by flinging open Europe’s borders to a million Syrian migrants.But voters’ resentment towards arrogant EU leaders — recorded by their own Eurostat polling system — long predates immigration.Embattled French President Emmanuel Macron recently admitted he had dared not offer his voters a “Frexit”  ­referendum — because they would leave in a flash.Weeks later, his fears were confirmed as “yellow-vest” anarchists set Paris ablaze.French observers believe the gilets jaunes riots have their origins in another referendum crisis.In , France voted overwhelmingly against the European Constitution — only to see it renamed the Lisbon Treaty and slyly introduced against their express wishes.The European Constitution, like the disastrous euro, was a crucial but unpopular step towards a federal European superstate.Ireland and ­Denmark have also voted down EU moves to ever-closer union.They were told to vote again until they said Yes.Brussels’ arrogant contempt for ordinary voters — dismissed by one French president as “scum” — is what politicians blithely describe as the “democratic deficit”.It sowed the seeds for Brexit. Immigration simply brought it to a head.Germany’s letter to The Times reads like a plea from a deserted lover.“Without your great nation, this continent would not be what it is today — a community defined by freedom and ­prosperity,” writes Germany’s next Chancellor.“Should Britain wish to leave the European Union for good, it will always have friends in Germany and Europe.”This is precisely what British voters hoped for as they ­teetered on the brink of Remain but opted to Leave.They wanted a civilised orce between economic and diplomatic allies.This is still possiblethe border issue can be resolved.If we can persuade the IRA to decommission deadly weapons, surely we can decommission a backstop that nobody wants Theresa May’s rejected deal is not a total failure. Without this problem it could still fly.Germany holds the key.If Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer means what she said about friendship, now is the time to prove it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit dozens tory ministers ready
story: NewsBrexit: DOZENS of Tory ministers ready to quit over No Deal warns Amber RuddTory Cabinet minister Amber Rudd is said to have made the warning to Downing Street as MPs face a new Brexit showdownShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsTheresa May is facing a new threatshe fails to let MPs vote on a No Deal Brexit"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Up to  Tory ministers are poised to quitTheresa May forces through plans for a No Deal Brexit , a top Cabinet minister has warned. Amber Rudd is understood to have told Downing Street it could suffer the exodus unless ministers get a say on blocking No Deal. Ms Rudd is said to want a free vote on plans that would allow the  March Brexit date to be extendedtheres no agreement. The Work and Pensions Secretarys private warning, reported by multiple media outlets including The Times, was backed up by a government source. It comes after Ms Rudd refused to rule out resigningthe government pursues No Deal.  At an event attended by the Mirror this month she said: I have been in and out of Cabinet and I find you have more influence in Cabinet. But she did not rule out leaving the government. Other ministers including Richard Harrington and Steve Brine have suggested publicly they could go. And Defence Minister Tobias Ellwood yesterday made a thinly-veiled call to delay Brexit - using the analogy of a cake. Posting a photo of his son eating the cake, he said: Cooked a banana cake yesterday. Told my son it will be ready in  mins - according to the cookbook. It took . It was a big decision - honouring the cookbook or take more time to get the right result. Ms Rudd is believed to want a free vote on a plan by Yvette Cooper, the Labour MP, that is due for a vote next Tuesday.   The plan would force Theresa May to ask the EU to extend the  March date of Brexit -there is no new deal by February . Theresa May pooh-poohed calls to extend the date of Brexit last night but did not altogether rule it out. Today, Brexit Secretary StephenBarclaywarned the EU might not support an extension to the date - eventhe UK asked for one. He told the BBC: It is not in the unilateral gt of the UK to extend. There are practical issues. They have been very clear that they dont want an extension with no purpose. And so we come back to the issue as to what it is MPs are for and just what they are against.  Ms Coopers plan is the leading contender in a string of amendments by MPs which seek to block a No Deal Brexit or delay the date. The amendments will be voted on next Tuesday night. Theresa May is still trying to get agreement to renegotiate her Brexit deal, which suffered a record defeat last week. She wants MPs to ask for tweaks to the backstop clause to stop it trapping the UK under EU customs rules. But EU chiefs have already dismissed this plea. And today it is reported that Mrs Mays chief civil service negotiator, Olly Robbins, cast doubt on her plan by texting Chancellor Philip Hammond - during a Cabinet conference call.

title: brexit labour not suddenly swung
story: NewsBrexit: Why Labour has NOT suddenly swung behind a second referendumLabour has spelt out more detail of its plan for Brexit - including a vote on a second referendum. Heres an explanation of what the plan actually means, and why its less simplistic than some might suggestShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video listen-interview-shadow-business-secretary-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLate last night, Labour unveiled its latest plan for Brexit. It was hailed by backers of a second EU referendum, who called it a big step forward and grabbing the Brexit bull by the horns. Anti-Peoples Vote MPs then hit back warning they wont support going back to the public. One newspaper called it Corbyn backs plan for second referendum. But amid all the sound and fury, what Labour has suggested isnt actually as dramatic as you might think. Heres a quick explanation of Jeremy Corbyns amendment, what it will do - and what it wont do.  Labour has unveiled an amendment to Theresa Mays Brexit plan ahead of a string of showdown votes by MPs next Tuesday night. If MPs pass it, the Prime Minister would be forced to give MPs a vote on options to prevent a No Deal Brexit on March . Those options would have to include:Negotiating changes to the Brexit deal to secure Labours demands - a permanent customs union with the EU, a strong relationship with the single market and dynamic alignment on workers rights. A second referendum, but only on a deal or a proposition that has commanded the support of the majority of the House of Commons.Why are people excited about it   Since September, Labour has been sitting on the fence about exactly how it should solve Brexit. Jeremy Corbyn has kept a second referendum as one option on the table, which apes a motion activists passed at the party conference. Activists are now demanding he swing % behind a second EU referendum after his bid to force a general election didnt succeed. So this new motion, promising a vote down the line on holding a second referendum, has caused lots of excitement. What do second referendum supporters say   Labour MP David Lammy of the anti-Brexit Peoples Vote campaign said: It is a big step forward that for the first time my party is acknowledging in a parliamentary amendment that a People’s Vote may be the only way forward. At the same time, the leadership is saying that Labour’s own Brexit plan should now take centre stage as this crisis unfolds.It is right that any proposal for Brexit deserves to be properly scrutinised. It is only when MPs have had the chance to look properly at these proposals, along with Norway Plus and a catastrophic no deal departure from the EU that they will really be able to decide whether they meet the promises made for Brexit in  and are at least as good as the deal we already have inside Europe. TSSA General Secretary Manuel Cortes said: This is an exemplary and timely amendment with Labour now grabbing the Brexit bull by its horns as May continues to pander to the far right in her party and outside it.“By all means, Labour must now push the government to negotiate a damage limiting Brexit and it is right that our Party now insist that the British people have sign off on any deal.Of course, not agreeing to the deal and staying as we are must be an option when the people do get that final say. But what do allies of Jeremy Corbyn say   Labour suggest the amendment is simply being faithful to the partys conference motion. Shadow business secretary Rebecca Long Bailey said it does not in any way mean the party is backing a second referendum - yet. Instead she told the BBC: The amendment is very specically-worded to allow for the debate of the options. It is not stating that the party supports a second referendum in any way. And indeedit was passed, the amendment, and it went to a vote on the specic issues, then that would be a decision for the party to take at the time. We are prioritising seeking a deal which provides many of the assurances we have sought from the PM. Plus - the amendment may well not pass  Leading Tory Remainers, such as Anna Soubry, have suggested they wont back Labours Plan B amendment. Without the support of a good number of Tory rebels, the amendment is unlikely to pass through Parliament. If thats the case, the MPs vote on a second referendum wouldnt happen. And a Peoples Vote might not have a majority... Under Labours plan a Peoples Vote would need a majority of support in Parliament in order to be held. Supporters of a second referendum concede it might not have a majority in Parliament yet. So has anything changed  Well of course, yes - Labour has laid out more of its plan and the path it wants to tread from here. The promise of a vote on a second EU referendum brings the party a small step closer to backing one, somewhere down the line. Butyou think itll mean a snap EU referendum just yet - you may be a little disappointed. Full text of Labours amendment [This House] “requires ministers to secure sufficient time for the UK Parliament to consider and vote on options to prevent the UK leaving the EU without a ratied Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration, and that those options should include:Negotiating changes to the draft Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration so as to secure a permanent customs union with the EU, a strong relationship with the single market underpinned by shared institutions and obligations, and dynamic alignment on rights and standards, in order to command a majority in the House of CommonsLegislating to hold a public vote on a deal or a proposition that has commanded the support of the majority of the House of Commons.”. What about all the other Plan Bs  You can read our full guide here.

title: brexit plan b explained amendments
story: NewsBrexit Plan B explained: Amendments to Theresa Mays deal and what they meanBrexits a smouldering wreck with barely two months to go. Here are the Plan Bs that are emerging, how MPs could take back control - and how the Queen could get dragged inShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan Bloom:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsMPs are planning to take control of the process "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit is a smouldering wreck after Theresa Mays deal suffered the worst defeat in House of Commons history. But out of the ashes, a string of radically dferent Plan B options are taking shape - and will wrestle for control in the Commons. The Prime Ministers own Plan B will go head to head with plans from Remain-backing MPs that could delay Brexit or stop it altogether. Labour wants to leave with a customs union, while other Remainers want to force a second EU referendum. Importantly, MPs will hold a vote on some of these options at pm on Tuesday  January - giving Theresa May a mandate toto the EU. Although the vote on her neutral motion isnt binding - what would be called an indicative vote - it will spell the way forward. So what are the biggest amendments that have been proposed so far and what will they do  Heres our rolling guide, which well continue to update as the vote draws near. Theresa Mays Plan B: Rework the Irish backstop and go back to EU in February  Theresa May ed to MPs on Monday  January to outline her own Plan B. She suggested she simply wants to tweak her -page Brexit deal - including a backstop that could trap the UK under EU customs rules - instead of ripping the whole thing up. The PM did not categorically rule out the customs union demanded by Labour - or, crucially, extending the  March date of Brexit. But she tried to rebuff calls for a customs union, a second referendum, ruling out No Deal, or revoking or extending the  March date of Brexit. Mrs May said she will continue with further meetings this week and consult this House on its negotiating mandate before ing to the EU to try and agree a further Plan B. She also offered confidential briefings to MPs on the way forward, guarantees on workers rights, and consultation with parliaments committees. Yet key figures in the EU savaged Mrs Mays Plan B pleas as party politics. And Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn told MPs: The Prime Ministers invitation to talks has been exposed as a PR sham. Contrary to what the Prime Minister just said there was no flexibility, there were no negotiations - nothing hadchanged. WILL IT SUCCEED  Unlikely. Itd need to EU to reopen talks on the backstop - a red line for Brussels. Itd also need around  Tory Brexiteers to cave in and decide Mays deal is the only way to prevent Brexit being stopped.  Jeremy Corbyns party has tabled an amendment which calls for Parliament to have a say on all the options. Theyd include Labours own Brexit plan - a Norway plus style agreement - and also the option for a second referendum. Party sources say the amendment is in line with the partys conference motion, which called for all options to be on the table. Labour believes its version of Brexit which would include a permanent customs union, relationship with the single market and alignment on rights and standards could get a Commons majority. But a growing number of Labour MPs want a second vote - and more than % of the partys membership also back another poll. Peoples Vote supporters hailed the amendment as a major step forward to a public ballot. But shadow minister Rebecca Long-Bailey denied it made a second referendum much more likely. Jeremy Corbyn said: Our amendment will allow MPs to voteon options to end this Brexit deadlock and prevent the chaos of a No Deal.WILL IT SUCCEED  Unlikely. Tory Remainers signalled early on they would not side with Labours motion.   A key amendment would force Theresa May to extend the  March date of Brexit -there is no new deal by February . It is being led by Labour MP Yvette Cooper and Tory MP Nick Boles, both Remain-backers. Specically, it would allow MPs to vote on a motion directing Mrs May to request an extension of the Article  date from EU chiefs. Theres speculation that Mrs May secretly supports this because it will allow her to extend Article  without getting her hands dirty. Ms Cooper, who chairs the Commons Home Affairs Committee, said: I think sheknows that she should rule out no deal in the national interest because it would be so damaging. Shes refusing to do so and I think shes hoping that Parliament will do this for her - that is not leadership. WILL IT SUCCEED  It has a fair chance. Tory Remainers Oliver Letwin and Nicky Morgan already back the bid, andthe Labour frontbench joins in, it has a reasonable prospect of passing. Dominic Grieve: Backbenchers can take control of them agree   A second, more radical amendment, drawn up by former Attorney General Dominic Grieve, would allow something big. MPs would be able to take control of the timetable in the House of Commons - by a minority voting for it. Usually the government has control of the agenda in the Commons, which stops backbenchers going rogue and passing laws. But under Mr Grieves plan,formal business it proposed by at least  of the  MPs - from at least five parties and including  Tories - it would be debated as the first item of Commons business the next day. Downing Street figures branded it a coup. But Mr Grieve said it would enable the Commons to vote on a string of alternatives. These could include a soft Norway-style deal or a second referendum. WILL IT SUCCEED  Its quite possible, but expect Tory MPs to wobble at something thats been branded a coup. Alliance of the forces of enlightenment Supporters of the Cooper Grieve plans are understood to have agreed to come together. One MP involved in the discussions told HuffPost: “It looks like the forces of enlightenment will be advancing on several compatible fronts when it comes to amendments.” It is understood the two camps will table compatible motions. These stand a good chance of passing with the combined weight of supporters for both amendments and the support of the Labour leadership. The Labour leader told the Commons on Monday: “We will, as we have said consistently from the beginning, back amendments that seek to rule out the disaster of no deal.” Hilary Benn: Let MPs choose between four ways forward  A separate amendment by Hilary Benn, chairman of the Commons Brexit Committee, would give MPs indicative votes on the way forward. MPs would choose from dferent options to see which would come out on top. They are:Another vote on Theresa Mays deal A No Deal Brexit Renegotiate the deal with EU to achieve a specic outcome A second EU referendumWILL IT SUCCEED  This amendment has emerged late so its chances of success are not yet clear. A doctors amendment: A straight vote on a second EU referendum  Pro-EU MPs who happen to be doctors are preparing to call for a straight vote on a second referendum, The Sun reports. Tory Dr Sarah Wollaston is leading the bid along with Tory ex-Minister Dr Philip Lee, Labour’s Dr Paul Williams and Dr Philippa Whitford of the SNP. Ms Wollaston told the newspaper: “It’s all about informed consent. You wouldn’t opt for surgeryyou didn’t know the operation you were having. And here, Theresa May is the surgeon.” WILL IT SUCCEED  The MPs involved are reasonably respected, but not enough detail is known yet. Plus - how the Queen could get dragged in   Theresa May could drag the Queen into a showdown with Parliament,MPs try to cancel or postpone Brexit. Former top government lawyer Sir Stephen Laws said trying to change the law in this way through an amendment, without the Government’s participation, could create a constitutional crisis. In a paper for the Policy Exchange think tank, Sir Stephen said: “It could raise a question whether the Government would be entitled or might feel required to reassert its constitutional veto by advising the Queen not to grant Royal Assent to the Bill. “How should the Monarch react to such advice  The answer is not straightforward and the prospect of it needing to be considered in a real le political crisis is unthinkably awful. “It is a sacred duty of all UK politicians not to involve the Monarch in politics. They have a constitutional responsibility to resolve dficulties between themselves in accordance with the rules, and so as not to call on the ultimate referee.”

title: theresa mays brexit groundhog day
story: NewsTheresa Mays Brexit "Groundhog Day" with Plan B almost identical to Plan AThe Prime Minister failed to impress with her latest updates while fuelling speculation that she may delay Brexit and extend Article ShareCommentsByPippa Crerar:,  JAN NewsMay has been warned by Amber Rudd that dozens of MPs are ready to quit next week unless she rules out a no deal Brexit "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May was accused of being stuck in a Brexit “Groundhog Day” after presenting a Plan B almost identical to her rejected Plan A. The Prime Minister told MPs she will press the EU for more concessions on the unpopular backstop. Government insiders said they hope the EU would be spooked by the clock running down to a no-deal scenario. But it was far from clear that the bloc was willing to give enough ground. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said nothing had changed, despite the PM’s deal being rejected by a record margin last week. He said: “What makes her think what she tried to renegotiate in December will succeed in January  This really does feel like Groundhog Day.”  There was just one major U-turn, with Mrs May saying she was scrapping the pound fee for EU citizens to stay after Brexit, at a cost of poundmillion. Otherwise, the changes were cosmetic. There was little detail on her offer of legal protections for workers’ rights and environmental safeguards and she refused to rule out leaving with no deal as it would not be “honest”. And she suggested a second referendum could “damage social cohesion” by undermining faith in democracy. MPs countered that her approach to Brexit was causing the real ision. Downing Street later denied Mrs May was suggesting there could be riots. The PM also fuelled speculation she plans to delay Brexit Day by refusing to explicitly rule out extending Article . When pressed, she rowed back from a previous commitment to say she was working on a deal “such that we can leave” the bloc.  Welfare Secretary Amber Rudd has warned dozens of ministers are ready to quit next week unless no-deal Brexit is ruled out. The Remainer believes ministers should get a free vote on extending Article . With cross-party talks stalling, the PM’s bid to break the deadlock looked doomed. Senior Tories persuaded her any attempt to compromise with Labour would terminally split their party. Instead, her focus was on offering Brexit bribes to the DUP and hardline MPs over the backstop on the Irish border – and the overtures showed early signs of working. The DUP’s Nigel Dodds praised the PM for “good engagement” and “willingness to try and reach a consensus”. Insiders clung to suggestions from Poland of a five-year time limit on backstop plans. But EU chiefs once again ruled out any changes. Chief negotiator Michel Barnier said Mrs May already had the “best possible” deal. And Irish deputy PM Simon Coveney said a backstop end-date did not represent EU thinking.  Tory Remainers were furious at the PM’s bid to win over Brexiteers and Anna Soubry said: “Here we are with another week of can-kicking – and the truth is, shynothing’s changed.” Sarah Wollaston added: “It’s like last week’s vote never happened. Plan B is Plan A.” Labour MPs were also angry, with Angela Eagle accusing the PM of “playing chicken” with her own shyBrexiteers and the DUP. It came as senior backbenchers began tabling amendments to the Brexit plan to let MPs take control. Labour’s Yvette Cooper was planning a move to delay departure and leading Tory rebel Dominic Grieve plans for MPs to get an “indicative vote” to seeany other deal option could win a majority. But they both need Mr Corbyn’s backing and the Labour leadership is eyeing all proposals with caution. Downing Street said Parliament was unlikely to have a second binding vote on the PM’s deal until February – playing down the shyimportance of next week’s vote. Meanwhile, former Government lawyer Sir Stephen Laws said the PM could drag the Queen into a showdown with ParliamentMPs try to cancel or postpone Brexit – but this could create a constitutional crisis.

title: ancient stone circle experts thought
story: NewsAncient stone circle that experts thought was , years old is s replicaThe Leochel-Cushnie stone circle in Aberdeenshire, was thought to date back thousands of years - until a farmer admitted it was a replicsShareCommentsByDouglas BarrieToby Meyjes:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe stone circle was thought to date back thousands of years "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA stone circle thought to date back thousands of years has been revealed as a replica built in the s. Archaeologists had hailed the discovery when it was made in Leochel-Cushnie, Aberdeenshire, back in November. However, weeks later they realised their blunder when a local farmer got in touch to say it was a model. Neil Ackerman, historic environment record assistant at Aberdeenshire Council, said: It is obviously disappointing to learn of this development, but it also adds an interesting element to its story.   That it so closely copies a regional monument type shows the local knowledge, appreciation and engagement with the archaeology of the region by the local community. I hope the stones continue to be used and enjoyed - while not ancient, it is still in a fantastic location and makes for a great feature in the landscape. Recumbent stone circles often date back ,-, years and are unique to the north-east of Scotland.   Mr Ackerman added: These types of monument are notoriously dficult to date. For this reason we include any modern replicas of ancient monuments in our records in case they are later misidentied. We always welcome reports of any new, modern reconstructions of ancient monuments, especially those built with the skill of this stone circle and that reference existing monument types.

title: cover up over grenfell style
story: NewsCover up over Grenfell-style cladding that burns at C in just  minutesEXCLUSIVE: Leaked footage handed to the Mirror shows flames shooting up cladding being used on blocks today - in a test which construction firm bosses tried to hide in a non-disclosure agreementShareCommentsByNick Sommerlad:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsFlames leaped up a replica wall and reached temperatures of over C"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds of residents are living at a tower block shycovered in cladding similar to that in the Grenfell disaster. One  failed a fire test in Dubai which should have lasted at least an hour after just  minutes. But families were not told for weeks and the firm which built the X shyEastlands block in Manchester tried to cover up the shock results. Fire safety expert Geoff Wilkinson said: “It is immoral.” With the furore from Grenfell still raging, residents of other tower blocks would expect to be toldtheir buildings have similar shycladding to that in the killer blaze. But families living in one were kept in the dark after  covering their homes failed a fire test within just two months of the inferno – a move branded “immoral” by safety experts. And there was fury as the firm that built the block tried to “cover up” the shocking results by demanding those who carried out the examination signed non-disclosure agreements. Leaked test footage handed to the Mirror showed flames leaping up a replica cladded wall within  minutes and reaching temperatures of more than C –  minutes quicker than the recommended guidelines. The exercise was abandoned after  minutes over safety fears. But residents at the eight-storey X Eastbank block in Manchester were not told about the test until seven week later, when we approached them.  Construction firm Forrest went into shyadministration allegedly without passing the damning test report on to the buildings’ owners. It comes as latest government figures show just five out of  private residential blocks have had their Grenfell-style shycladding, or aluminium composite material, removed.  Building inspector and fire safety expert Geoff Wilkinson said: “If this building failed its test so quickly then that is indicating that there is a risk of external fire spread. The correct and moral thing to do is to remove the cladding and replace it.   “The moral thing is certainly to make the residents aware. It is immoral not to have notied someone there is an issue and that you are putting measures in place. You should be aiming to review the information and putting shymeasures in place within a week or two at the most.” Resident Kostas shyDespotelis, , added: “We have heard nothing about this test. It is worrying.” shy Neighbour Nadia Elzenaty said: “We were not aware of this. I knew a lot of companies were testing this cladding after the fire at Grenfell. It is shydisappointing. X should have someone chasing this up.  “They have a duty of care. There are a lot of tenants in this building. I know it is expensive to fix but you cannot undo the damage of lives lost.” Building regulations require a -minute fire protection barrier between shyapartments in a block. In August , Eastbank was found to have potentially dangerous cladding in a fire brigade shyinspection. But a blaze spread test was not carried out until  months later. Emails seen by the Mirror show the Dubai-based testing firm told Forrest on November : “The assembly fire test was conducted today at our facility.  “Please be informed that the assembly did not meet the acceptable criteria stated in BR  classication standard [for fire performance of external thermal insulation].” Forrest, which was in financial shydficulty, did not pay for the test in full and two weeks later demanded the firm signed a NDA. It wrote: “It’s a v simple shydocument, it merely says that you won’t pass details of the test on to rd parties.” A representative of the testing firm replied: “Why is this requiredForrest is taking the appropriate steps to ensure the safety of the building and its residents  “Signing the NDA blind would then implicate me in any cover up … I am not prepared to allow the people living in that building to be exposed to that kind of risk.” A Forrest employee replied on December  that “unless the NDA is signed we are reluctant to pay it. That’s the position of our main board not me personally”. Nick Sweeney, chief executive officer at X Developments, which owns the property, confirmed his firm knew the test had taken place and had been “made aware” of the shypreliminary findings received by Forrest. He said Forrest had “indicated that the [cladding] assembly did not meet the BR  classication” but had not handed over the test report. Mr Sweeney insisted additional fire safety measures were put in place when the cladding was first identied, including a “waking watch” to alert tenants to evacuate a fire. He said the building was “safe and habitable”. He added: “We’ve been awaiting the final report so we can then consider what works are required to the building.  “X have received a preliminary statement from Forrest but the draft report had not been provided to X prior to you providing the redacted version of the draft report. “We are meeting our professional team to discuss its contents and we will be putting in place such shyremediation strategy as is necessary. “X has delivered letters via email and through a hand delivery through each door informing the residents that the cladding system is being tested and informing them of the enhanced fire safety which has been adopted. “X has agreed an enhanced fire strategy with the fire officer which will remain until the testing has been completed andrequired any shyremedial works undertaken. “X was not aware of the emails between Forrest and [the testing company] nor of the NDA. The NDA is irrelevant to X as we will not be bound by it and will be providing, as we have done to date, full shyinformation we hold to both the fire officer and the government department.” Since being contacted by the Mirror, X has announced it “will be removing the cladding which is affixed to part of the exterior of the building and replacing it with a new system”. The administrators of Forrest would not comment.  Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service said Eastbank was inspected in  and the shycladding was “considered to present a risk of external fire spread”. A spokesman added: “A change to the evacuation strategy was agreed. A number of actions were agreed including the provision of a waking watch in line with guidance from the Government and this was shyimplemented immediately.” The fire service will now “monitor plans to remove and replace the cladding”. X Eastbank, where the  flats cost between pound and pound, a month to rent, was completed in . The Grenfell blaze was started by a faulty fridge freezer at the block in North Kensington, West London, on June , . It spread up the external cladding on the -storey council building, killing  people. Police are considering offences including shycorporate manslaughter. The tragedy sparked a review of building safety. The Ministry for Housing, shyCommunities and Local Government identied  high-rise blocks with ACM [aluminium composite material] cladding, including the  privately-owned ones. Apart from the five private towers that had it removed, figures released last week showed work was underway on another nine. Owners of  blocks said they had “remediation plans in place”, while  “intended” to remediate. But in  buildings shyremediation plans were “unclear”. The Government has spent poundmillion replacing such  on social housing but private owners are accused of lagging behind. Mr Sweeney said X had removed ACM at two blocks but did not reveal whether other X buildings had been identied with the shycladding.

story: NewsHovis bread, Coco Pops, Maltesers, MMs and Minstrels are all SHRINKINGProducts from household brands such as Hovis and Coco Pops have been among the shrinking staples, along with a couple of very well known chocolate barsShareCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor:,  JAN NewsHovis Best of Both was g and has shrunk to g - and thats not the only well known product to have pared down in size "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShrinkflation has hit bread and cereals harder than other products in recent years, a study reveals. Office for National Statistics research on , items found  were reduced in size while their prices stayed the same between September  and June . And the bread and cereal category had the most cases with  goods – including  breakfast cereals and three loaves. It comes after Hovis shrank the size of its Best of Both from g to g in . title: inside ticket tout kings luxury
story: NewsInside ticket tout kings luxury £m mansion bought with overpriced gig salesAndrew Newman has snapped up one of the countrys most luxurious new build homes, after making an estimated £million from selling overpriced tickets to gigs at venues across ScotlandShareCommentsByMark McGivernAbigail OLeary:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAndrew Newman with his new fiancée Melanie Rein "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the luxury poundmillion mansion bought by a man dubbed the King of ticket touts. Andrew Newman has snapped up one of the countrys most luxurious new build homes, after making an estimated poundmillion from selling overpriced tickets to gigs at venues across Scotland. The tout, who also works as a computer and IT expert, is reported to have had dealings with thousands of people desperate to see their favourite artists, in venues such as Glasgow’s SSE Hydro. Many of those customers have forked out hundreds more than the original sale price of a ticket, reports the Daily Record. Newman has also been pictured with his German fianceacutee Melanie Rein, who has previously spoken about their luxury lestyle on Facebook.   His move to the opulent new home came to light after ticket site Viagogo was forced to start naming some of the biggest touts on their books. And a court order won by the Competition and Markets Authority at the High Court forced the site to list some of its biggest touts. This showed Newman has moved his North Financial Group Ltd business to his exclusive new countryside home. Claire Turnham, who won an MBE for her work campaigning with the Victim of Viagogo pressure group,said Newmans show of wealth after fleecing people was stomach turning.   She said: Clearly there’s a lot of money to be made from fleecing people via industrial scale ticket touting. To see such vast displays of wealth is galling and stomach turning to those who have suffered because of it. Newman bought the pound,milion, five-bedroom home in October last year. The homes features include three acres of garden, a stable block and a separate acre paddock, a heated balcony and a triple car garage.   It also comes with a separate one bedroom flat. Newmans fianceacutee Rein has spoken of their romance via her public shyFacebook, and earlier this year announced she is expecting a baby in a post reading: We wish everyone a happy New Year! For us, the best is yet to come in June . Rein has also posted photos revealing how Newman wooed her by taking her ringside at WWE wrestling events before enjoying exotic holidays in Dubai.   Reins profile also lists Ed Sheeran as one of her favourite artists - despite Sheeran being the worlds biggest anti-tout performer. Sheeran has led the way in trying to combat touts by laying down terms and conditions that forbid the likes of Newman from shyprofiting off the back of his talent. A statement from Viagogo read: Viagogo is a marketplace and doesn’t buy or sell tickets. Viagogo provides a  for third party sellers to sell tickets to event goers.Viagogo does not set ticket prices, sellers set their own prices, which may be above or below the original face value.The tickets sold on Viagogo’s  are genuine tickets that have been sold on by the original ticket purchaser in good faith.

title: michael mcintryres big show singer
story: NewsMichael McIntyres Big Show singer attacked by stalker ex after performanceRachel Crowe, , was stalked and assaulted by her ex James Hall on the same day she became the comedians unexpected star on the Saturday night programmeShareCommentsByJon HarrisAbigail OLeary:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video rachel-crowe-sings-michael-mcintyres-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who appeared on the BBCs Michael McIntyre’s Big Show has said she she is living in fear of her jealous ex-boyfriend after he harassed her following her TV appearance. Singer Rachel Crowe, , was stalked and assaulted by her ex James Hall on the same day she became the comedians unexpected star on the Saturday night programme. On January , Hall approached Miss Crowe in a bar and followed her to her car where he grabbed her by the arm and pulled her to the floor. When she managed to get into her vehicle, he attempted to rip her wing mirror off and jumped on the car bonnet as she attempted to leave. On another occasion, Hall, , from Bolton, Greater Manchester went to Miss Crowes home and woke her up during the early hours banging on the front window, begging her to take him back.He also hounded Miss Crowe with  emails in just three days from dferent email addresses, one such being “pleaseRacheldontdothis@gmail”.In a statement to police Miss Crowe, a trained opera singer who also works as a choreographer, said: I feel scared and afraid to leave my house. I’m afraid of coming across the defendant whilst I’m out because of these incidents.   “He can be angry and aggressive. He could hurt me. I find his behaviour intimidating and worrying. As I am a singer, I am worried he could turn up as I’m working, which is what has happened on previous occasions.” At Manchester magistrates Court, Hall, a former accounts student, pleaded guilty to assault by beating and the stalking of Miss Crowe. He appeared emotionless as he was handed a  week prison sentence suspended for  months. Prosecuting, Carl Gaffney said: “The aggrieved Miss Rachel Crowe and the defendant were in a relationship for  months. She describes an escalation regarding his behaviour towards her, and she used words such as ‘jealous’, ‘bullying’ and ‘aggressive’ to describe his behaviour towards her. “In October last year they split up. There were two sets of incidents. Firstly, there were hundreds of emails sent to the complainant from a number of dferent addresses which had been found. “Some of them were made out to be humorous in an attempt to be playful, but this was beyond inappropriate. For example, one of the email addresses was “ pleaseRacheldontdothis@gmail ”.“It was a dull echo of what it was like when she could have been with him, it was described. The emails are benign. The emails became far more frequent as he asked to be taken back. “His behaviour towards her showed that he talked about their physical tendencies. There were a number of incidents also. “The aggrieved goes out on January th. She is out with a friend when he appeared in the same bar demanding to speak to her.   “He appears in front of her face. She manages to escape when her group go to a dferent bar. He followed her into the bar but he was refused entry to the establishment. She became successful in hiding. “However, when she leaves to go to her car out the back, he grabbed her by the arm and pulled her to the ground. She managed to get up and get into her car and locked it. “He then started trying to rip her wing mirror off before jumping on the bonnet of her car trying to stop her from leaving. He was taken off the bonnet by assisting people. “On Janaury th the aggrieved was at her home address when the second incident occurred. He was outside her address uninvited and unsolicited. She was woken up by banging on the windows as the defendant attempted to gain entry. “She was concerned about the noise so went to the front of her address and the defendant was there, begging to get in, but she refused. She remained at the front of the address and she phoned the police and texted her mother and told her she needed to come due to him being outside.   “The defendant then moved round to the back of the address and climbed into the rear garden where he continued banging on the rear door shouting at the aggrieved to let him in. “The defendant was there for up to two hours before he left the address. The police did not come in that timescale. After being arrested, he made signicant admissions and there was immediately no hesitation to guilty pleas. He is a man of a certain physical stature. The court heard Hall had previously appeared before magistrates in Cumbria last November for criminal damage after he had a bust up with Miss Crowe during a wedding.   A probation report compiled by an unnamed author said: “He tells me he didn’t pull the victim to the floor at all, though he did acknowledge jumping on the car bonnet when he thought she was going to drive at him. “Regarding the texts and emails, he said he did make contact as described, but said the victim had sometimes responded to his contact and he said this caused him to make further contact. He used her response to his emails as justication for his actions without giving considerable thought for the impact on the victim. “He said this was a turbulent relationship with the victim because of his alcohol misuse, caused by his dficulties sleeping. This was an angry reaction to the breakdown of the relationship. He kept his own thoughts above that of his victims. He would benefit from intervention to address the offending of this nature.” Halls lawyer Nick Ross said: “He recognises this is over and it’s sensible for this to be over. Regarding the conviction for criminal damage, he ‘kicked off’ at a wedding whilst in drink. He caused some damage to some items at the wedding. He found himself homeless after a fall out with his father. “His behaviour was very persistent, but only over a few days. It was not his place or position to place his arm out to restrain her, it was a little more persistent on the arm of the complainant. He did do that and recognised he was overstepping the line. This assault was not a punch or a kick or a slap.”   Hall was also ordered to complete a two year community order, pay pound costs and he was ordered to engage in a Building Better Relationships programme. Sentencing Deputy District Judge Thomas Moran said: “You have clearly got a problem with relationships and you have come close to receiving a prison sentence judging by the way you pursued your former partner who is clearly terried of you. “I order for there to be no compensation offered - that is the last thing she is interested in. What she wants you to do is leave her alone,you don’t you will find yourself back here and going to prison.” Hall was also made subject of a restraining order for five years, which prohibits him from making any contact with Miss Crowe or attending her address.

title: mr loophole lawyer reveals prince
story: NewsMr Loophole lawyer reveals why Prince Philip should NOT apologise for car crashNick Freeman, a celebrity lawyer, believes there Duke of Edinburgh has "no requirement" to do anything following his Sandringham accidentShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  JAN NewsPrince Philip was seen driving less than  hours after the collision in Norfolk "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Philip should not apologise for the car crash which left two women injured, according to celebrity lawyer Nick Freeman. Mr Freeman - nicknamed Mr Loophole - said there is there is no requirement for the Duke of Edinburgh to do anything as a criminal investigation has started. He said it would be wrong to apologise while liability or culpability for the crash has not been established. But Mr Freeman added thatthe duke is culpable, he should save taxpayers money and admit his guilt. A criminal investigation is going on so theres no requirement for the Duke of Edinburgh to do anything of provide anything, he said. If he apologises, he could be admitting hes guilty. The dukes Land Rover was in collision with a Kia carrying Emma Fairweather, an unnamed female friend and her a nine-month-old baby near to Sandringham on Thursday.   Ms Fairweather, who broke her wrist on the crash, claims she has not received an apology from the royal family even though she could have been killed. She told the Sunday Mirror: It would mean the world to mePrince Philip said sorry but I have no ideahes sorry at all. What would it have taken for him and the Queen to send me a card and a bunch of flowers   Ms Fairweathers friend also required hospital treatment but her baby was unhurt.Mr Freeman said in most accidents people dont apologise and the duke should keep his own counsel. He added: The duke has three options: wait and see what happens with the investigation, grab the nettle and cough up to what hed done and offer to surrender his licence or he can attempt to get round it.  Buthes guilty he could save the taxpayers tens of thousands of pounds and come out and say, I was at fault. The duke was reportedly overheard telling police at the scene that hed been dazzled by the sun. Mr Freeman previously said the duke could be prosecuted for driving without due care and attentionhe was deemed to have made a mistake. But, he added,the sun was so low that it was in his eyes and made it impossible to see, that could afford him a defence.

title: royals were normal theyd asbo
story: NewsopinionIf the Royals were normal theyd all have an ASBO - its time to get these loons off our roadsBritains attitude to Royal car crashes is a bit skew-wfShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinion"Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Philip was in a car crash in which everybody lived. But imagine, for a moment, that one little thing was dferent. Britain has been plunged into mourning by the death of Prince Philip in an horric car accident. In a tragic echo of Princess Dianas death  years ago, it is thought he was not wearing a seatbelt. The Queens strength and stay of  years was killed after he stopped his Land Rover at a junction and was hit by a second vehicle...Or perhaps: A Greek migrant is being hunted by police after crashing into a car carrying a young mum and baby on their way home from a day at the beach. The identity of the man, considered a menace by local road users, is known to officers. It is thought he is married to a local woman, although it is not clear whether he has a legal right to remain in the UK...Or even: Third-in-line to the throne Prince George escaped unscathed after his mum the Duchess of Cambridges car was in a smash on a death-trap road. The woman driver of the other vehicle, who also had a child in the back seat, was breath-tested at the scene... The fact a -year-old was involved in a collision has been used to demand older people resit their driving tests, have their licenses revoked and or be confined to barracks.But as the RAC has quite reasonably pointed out,you revoked the right to drive of those people most likely to have a smash, it would mean young people had the most to lose.So imagine a younger household name was involved: Road safety campaigners demanded footballer Raheem Sterling be jailed after a car smash with a young mum and baby. The controversial midfielder, , was seen getting behind the wheel again just a day later, and our exclusive pictures PROVE he didnt even wear a seatbelt. Young people are a bloody menace on the roads, said Prince Philip, while unveiling a plaque just a mile from the crash scene...But the problem isnt age. The problem is us, and our attitude to royalty. Had Raheem Sterling broken a womans wrist in a car accident, leaving her to get washed and dressed with help of her teenaged son, facing two months off work and possible surgery to rebreak the bones and a letime of that wrist never being quite right again, she wouldnt expect his girlfriend to send flowers. Anyone in that situation would more likely be spitting tacks at the thoughtless arsehole who caused a painful injury to a complicated joint that will require a year of rehabilitation, and would be demanding the insurance company screw him for every last penny.And theyd never expect a personal apology, on the grounds everyone in an accident knows admitting responsibility is something best left to the lawyers. The victim probably wouldnt say it could all be resolved with a phone call from Raheem askingshe was all right, because shes such a big fan of Man City.  And had Prince Philip been just about anyone , the accident might not have happened.The Royals do not know what traffic is, because they are never stuck in it. There are chauffeurs, advanced driving experts, and motorcycle outriders ensuring that they can whizz up the hard shoulder, shoot through the lights and ignore the right of way. When Philip drove his own London taxi to get around the capital, it was so he could AVOID traffic.When they get to wherever theyre going, the gates are open. Someone salutes. People wave. Everyone keeps clear of the wheels, which, of course, are always clean. You will never see a Royal in a car that has fingermarks in the weeks worth of road splatter around the doors. Youll never see their wing mirror with a ding or the wipers on their last swipe. Prince Andrew has been accused of ramming gates with his car at Windsor, and knocking over a police officer at the gates of Buckingham Palace. Princess Anne has been done for speeding at mph, and when Prince Edward was courting Sophie Rhys Jones her neighbours got used to ing into hedges to avoid being mown down as he whizzed along the country lane leading to her family home.They all do it. If that family lived in a Hackney high-rise, theyd all have an ASBO. Perhapsthey had experiences more like the rest of us, then when he pulled up to a T-junction where the sun was dazzling his vision the Duke of Edinburgh would have stopped until he could see there was no traffic.Someone with no experience of traffic, though, would assume the road was empty and just pull out. Andsomeone that daft and entitled was behind the wheel of what was literally an armoured vehicle - regardless of their age - theyd get nicked by police. If they had been ploughing into other cars on a semi-regular basis throughout their driving career, theyd get taken to court.Andthe police actually LIVED with them and spoke to them EVERY DAY, it would happen in minutes. Royals have always, traditionally, been pretty deadly. When they were around, serfs were more likely to be beaten, maids certain to be ravished, and large public protests far more likely to see their leaders run through with a sword. Wars were inevitable with every marital breakdown or romantic refusal.Removing some of their powers was a great idea, but giving them -wheel drive and several tons of moving metal to fling about the countryside at whim probably wasnt. The problem weve got is that we treat the Royals like a dferent species, and are disgusted when they act like one.We want manners and Britishness but we get rude Prussians, with fat fingers and tin ears. We bow and scrape and curtsey and mutter about why they arent a little more thoughtful, while removing from their lives all things that require deep thought - careers, taxation, a lack of opportunity.As long as we have a Royal Family that is allowed to own the place, they will continue to act like they do. Butwe demanded they had lives more like ours, they wouldnt be Royal any more - thered be nothing special about them, or perhaps more importantly us. Thats why we put up with them we like to think it rubs off.There is a solution, though: remove the gates from their palaces so they cant get out. Theyd still have lots of space to drive around, theres no traffic to bother them, and we all get to live another day.

story: NewsNew York could be swamped by ice melting FOUR times faster than  years agoGreenlands ice is melting rapidly and major American coastal cities could be swampedShareCommentsByToby Meyjes:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video greenlands-meltwater-increasing-rate-sea-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGreenlands ice is melting four times faster than just  years ago, and major American coastal cities such as New York could be swamped, scientists have warned. The ice is melting quicker than experts previously thought, and they say it will likely lead to faster sea level rises, due to the continued, accelerating warming of the Earths atmosphere. The study flies in the face of US President Donald Trump who has repeatedly denied the scientic consensus on climate change. He once claimed the phenomenon was a Chinese hoax intended to hurt American exports. Researchers concerned about global sea level rises have focused on Greenland, where large glaciers stream iceberg-sized chunks of ice into the Atlantic. The chunks float away, eventually melting.   But a new study, published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, found that the largest sustained ice loss from early  to mid- came from the countrys south-west region, which is mostly devoid of large glaciers. Study lead author Professor Michael Bevis, of The Ohio State University in the States, said: Whatever this was, it couldnt be explained by glaciers, because there arent many there. It had to be the surface mass - the ice was melting inland from the coastline. The melting, which Professor Bevis and his colleagues believe is largely caused by global warming, meaning growing rivers of water are streaming into the ocean during summer.   The key finding from their study is that parts Greenland, which previously had not been considered a serious threat, will likely become a major future contributor to sea level rise. Professor Bevis said: We knew we had one big problem with increasing rates of ice discharge by some large outlet glaciers. But now we recognise a second serious problem: increasingly, large amounts of ice mass are going to leave as meltwater, as rivers that flow into the sea. He said the findings could have serious implications for coastal US cities, including New York and Miami, as well as island nations that are particularly vulnerable to rising sea levels. And he warned there is no turning back.   The only thing we can do is adapt and mitigate further global warming - its too late for there to be no effect, he added. This is going to cause additional sea level rise. We are watching the ice sheet hit a tipping point. Climate scientists and glaciologists have been monitoring the Greenland ice sheet as a whole since  when NASA and Germany joined forces to launch the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment, known as GRACE. It involves twin satellites that measure ice loss across Greenland. Data from the satellites showed that between  and , Greenland lost around  gigatons of ice per year, equivalent to an annual sea level rise of . inches.   But the rate of ice loss across the island was far from steady. Professor Bevis team used data from GRACE and from GPS stations scattered around Greenlands coast to identy changes in ice mass. The patterns they found show an alarming trend - by , ice was being lost at nearly four times the rate that prevailed in . And the biggest surprise was that the acceleration was focused in south-west Greenland, a part of the island that previously hadnt been known to be losing ice that rapidly. The scholar’s findings are at complete odd to Trump’s views.   Only on Sunday, the US leader mocked the issue of climate change as eastern America was hit by temperatures as low as -C. He tweeted: “Be careful and try staying in your house. Large parts of the Country are suffering from tremendous amounts of snow and near record-setting cold. “Amazing how big this system is. Wouldn’t be bad to have a little of that good old fashioned Global Warming right now!” Trump was trolled on social media for his lack of understanding of climate change confusing it with simply cold weather.
