If there are downturns we can weather those storms.West Coastrsquos confidence in the Winchburgh plan has increased after the company won backing for the project from one of the UKrsquos biggest insurers and struck key agreements with the Scottish Government and West Lothian Council to support work on the related infrastructure.As well as providing homes for thousands of people, the development will include four new schools, a motorway spur, a giant public park and a new railway station.ldquoThe fact that we are building a new town and the station will be  minutes from Edinburgh Haymarket, to be able to build something on that scale is something quite exciting, observed Sir Tom.After losing some of the fortune he made from the poundm sale of his Sports Division business when investments in house builders went badly during the financial crisis, Sir Tom has persevered with plans for Winchburgh in the face of big challenges.Read more: Ayrshire entrepreneur flags focus on unlisted investmentsHe bought into the project in  in the belief that Winchburghrsquos location meant it was ideally placed to benefit from long term developments in the economy in the area only to find some firms dropped out amid the downturn triggered by the credit crunch.West Coast spent years trying to secure the public support needed to develop the infrastructure required to make plans for the town viable.The company announced yesterday that it had formed a joint venture with Cala Homes to invest in the development and delivery of the overall masterplan for Winchburgh.Details of the agreement have not been disclosed but Sir Tom said it will entail multi-million investment. He noted that Cala was acquired last year by le and pensions giant Legal  General, which has made clear it is ready to invest in the housebuilding sector in the long term.ldquoTheresrsquos some heavy lting going on now, said Sir Tom. ldquoRather than put in debt we decided to look for a partner who shared our long-term view.Cala will build some homes at Winchburgh. It will work with West Coast to complete the developments required to ensure other housebuilders buy land on the site. Sir Tom noted a first phase development won support from five housebuilders, including Miller and Taylor Wimpey. These built and sold around  homes.West Lothian Council will build two secondary and two primary schools, which will ultimately be paid for by house builders via receipts from the roof tax.The Building Scotland Fund is lending pound.m to support infrastructure investment.

title: Iain Macwhirter  MPs must work together to unblock Brexit  or they   ll open the way for authoritarians
story: So, we at least have breathing space, a pause, a moment for reflection. My own wish would be for MPs to seize the moment and vote to revoke Article  altogether. MPs have the power to stop the clock for good, thanks to the good works of legally-minded MPs like the SNPrsquos Joanna Cherry.Staying in the EU is the only sure way to stop the endless arguments about Canada plus, Norway plus, customs union, Irish backstop, regulatory alignment, maximum facilitation and all the rest of the gubbins thatrsquos been occupying our addled brains for the last two-and-a-half years. However, this isnrsquot going to happen.And Irsquod have to agree that it would be undemocratic for MPs to simply reverse the result of the  referendum by revoking A. It may be that Parliament has the power and the constitutional right to do so: referendums are only advisory. But it would leave so much unpleasantness that British politics would be soured for decades. There would have to be a referendum.This is where my unease turns to genuine anxiety. I have a horrible feeling that Labourrsquos Diane Abbott was right on Question Time this week when she said: ldquoBe careful what you wish for. She agrees with Nigel Farage that a repeat referendum is likely to endorse no-deal Brexit, perhaps by an even greater margin than in .Evenit left us with a mirror-image result, with say % Remain against % Leave, that would itself be a disaster because it would have no legitimacy. Yes, some opinion polls say Remain would win a comfortable majority, but they said that last time.The Brexiteers are already field-testing their slogans on social media. The frontrunner is ldquoTell Them Again, which may not be as resonant as ldquoTake Back Control but is still pretty hot. It surfs on the very widespread disgust and alienation that many ordinary people feel about the political elite. It appeals to democratic injustice: how dare the globalists ignore the result of , which David Cameron promised would be for keeps What would Remainrsquos slogan be  Itrsquos likely to be a repeat of the Project Fear line which failed dismally in . ldquoDonrsquot put your childrenrsquos prosperity at risk, perhaps, or ldquoThink Twice Think Jobs. But what many pro-Europeans fail to grasp ndash and this applied to the Unionists in the Scottish independence referendum ndash is that it ISNrsquoT the economy, stupid. Brexit voters donrsquot just make their decisions on the basis of economic rationality, as seen from the CBI and corporate Britain.People are always motivated more by emotion than numbers ndash on what they believe to be morally right. The sense that working-class people have lost control is a very potent mobiliser.As in war ndash and it is remarkable how much Brexit mythology harks back to World War Two ndash people are quite willing to sacrice some comfort for what they believe in.I may think they are mistaken. As with the people who supported Donald Trump because he promised to Make America Great Again, and bring back the jobs, I think Brexit voters have been sold a  prospectus by politicians who do not have the best interests of working people at their hearts.But that isnrsquot really the point. I can well understand the sense of injustice felt by people who have been left behind by global capitalism. They want to kick the system, and the referendum gave them a chance to do it. They need a very strong reason not to kick the metropolitans again. Only Labour can provide that reason, and Jeremy Corbyn has been singularly reluctant to do so.His refusal even to meet Theresa May was irresponsible in this climate. It may have allowed him to avoid coming off the fence, but it looked petty and weak. Corbyn should have gone in guns blazing, demanded that she drop the red lines, and then mobilised Labour for either rejoining the single market or for a referendum.Single market membership has always been the logic of Labourrsquos position, even though Corbyn usually refers to a ldquopermanent customs union. Only by joining the European Economic Area could Labour deliver friction-free trade, and protect environmental standards and workers rights. People say that Norway has blocked the UKrsquos entry to the European Economic Area, but this is not true. The Norwegian PM, Erna Solberg, has repeatedly made clear that Norway would have severe reservations ndashwho wouldnrsquot  ndash but would not block UK membership.This is because the EEA is essentially a Brussels creation. It was set up as a halfway house to membership of the EU back in  when a number of countries were uneasy about joining the political institutions of Europe. The EEA is just the European Single Market under another name.Brussels endorses British membership of the EEA, and this economic arrangement has a number of advantages over Mayrsquos deal. Therersquos no need for an Irish backstop no membership of the CAP and the Common Fisheries Policy no direct jurisdiction of the European Court and it costs less than EU membership. Of course, it does not bring the full benefits of EU membership. Britain would become a ldquorule taker on trade. But the EEA does not preclude future membership of the European Union. Norway, or any other member of the EEA, can opt for full membership at any time. And unlike the backstop, countries can leave the EEA after one year.Membership of the single market also means accepting freedom of movement, which is why it may well be rejected by Parliament. But it is the only option that has a snowballrsquos chance of getting a majority,Labour were to seriously support it. ldquoNorway plus, as itrsquos called, has more support than a repeat referendum. Fewer than  Labour MPs have called for a Peoples Vote, and only  Conservatives. The SNP has decided to throw its lot in with a repeat referendum, despite having argued convincingly for the single market for the last two years. But that isnrsquot enough.To repeat. Were it left to me, I would revoke Article  tomorrow. I just want this madness to stop. But given the metrics in Parliament, we have to look at the least worst options, as the Labour-supporting commentator Owen Jones put it last week. Mayrsquos deal is dead. MPs owe it to the country, and to themselves, to find some compromise that works. Perhaps that can only be achieved with a referendum. ButMPs fail this week, they risk destroying respect for parliamentary democracy, and opening the way for a more authoritarian form of political leadership.

title: equal-pay-glasgow-city-council-to-sell-assets-to-its-own-property-firm-to-fund-500m-deal

title: mark-smith-for-all-our-sakes-four-facts-about-the-snp-that-we-can-all-hopefully-agree-on
story: :Alex Salmond takes swipe at SNP leadership over IndyrefSo, in the spirit of trying to encourage more facts in a post-fact world, could I offer you four which I think we can rely on  I realise, of course, that some people will immediately look at my list and say theyrsquore not facts at all, theyrsquore opinion, but all I can say is that this is a genuine effort to distil the last few days of argument over the SNP, Nicola Sturgeon and the Alex Salmond investigation into four areas where I think most of us could find agreement. Here goes.The first one is this: the Salmond investigation is unlikely to change many minds on independence, which is where Walter Macfarlane comes in. Walter, I should explain, has been dead for  years but I only came across him for the first time a few days ago while I was reading the journals of the great Scottish diarist James Boswell. Boswell writes about meeting Macfarlane in the entry for Sunday  November  and describes him as a man who was ldquokeenly interested in the reigning contests between Scots  English.:Poll suggests SNPs credibility damaged by Alex Salmond allegationsldquoHe talked much against the Union, writes Boswell of his new friend. ldquoHe said we were perfect underlings, that our riches were carried out of the country, that no town but Glasgow had any advantage of trade by it, and that many others were hurt by it.Why am I bringing this up now  Mainly because it demonstrates something thatrsquos often forgotten, which is that unhappiness with the Union and support for independence is not a modern phenomenon, and itrsquos not all about the SNP either. As you can see from Boswellrsquos diary, Macfarlane was complaining about the Union just  years or so after the Act of Parliament that brought it about and  years before the SNP was even thought of. Which is the important point: independence has always been a strand of Scottish opinion and, seen in that long historical context, the travails of Nicola Sturgeonare unlikely to greatly change that one way or the other.The second fact is this: the Salmond investigation has emphasised that there are serious isions in the SNP. Some nationalists appear to be offended by this idea and deny there is any ision at all but the briefings of Salmond supporters against Sturgeon and vice versa speak for themselves. In fact, even as he made an apparent appeal to end the acrimony at the weekend, Alex Salmond couldnrsquot resist turning his handshake into a punch. He said he had ordered his team not to become involved in any more exchanges before criticising Sturgeon for not concentrating on independence. There may be some in the SNP who insist this doesnrsquot represent ision but then Baghdad Bob insisted there were no American troops in Iraq to the sound of American troops in Iraq.The third fact leads straight on from the ision in the SNP but is about nationalism more generally and itrsquos this: levels of support for both sides of the independence debate have not shted.In some ways, this third fact is the most surprising of all because, on the face of it, the circumstances are in place for a breakthrough on either side. For the opposition parties at Holyrood, therersquos the Salmond investigation and its implications for Sturgeon and yet support for the SNP has not changed, and for the nationalists, therersquos the crisis of Brexit and yet the polls continue to show  per cent of Scots want to remain in the UK. The nationalists may talk about a ldquosurge and the unionists may revel in the SNPrsquos crisis, but the polls havenrsquot changed. Thatrsquos a fact.Which leads us to the fourth, final, and perhaps most controversial fact: a second referendum on Scottish independence before  is less likely than it was two years ago. Partly, this is because of those polls againbut itrsquos also because of the logistics and timing. The reality now is that we may not know ndash even by  ndash what Brexit is going to look like and Sturgeon herself has said there will be no announcement until the fog has cleared. Then therersquos the clincher: there is no prospect of a Section  order giving permission for a referendum from the Conservative Government. Thatrsquos a fact many of those in the independence movement simply pretend does not exist.:Calls for public inquiry into "unlawful" handling of sexual misconduct complaints against Alex SalmondThe effect of all of these facts, as Irsquove confidently called them, is another matter entirely and depends on how much the politicians resist them. In the wake of the Salmond investigation, itrsquos certainly hard to imagine the SNP fighting the  election campaign with any of the confidence it had in  and , and even in , but then again therersquos every chance Nicola Sturgeon will stick to the grid and announce a referendum before  in the hope that its rejection by the UK Government will increase support for her position.Should that happen, I have honestly no ideathe strategy would work ndash the facts donrsquot stretch that far ndash but maybe now would be a good time toto the diaries of James Boswell for some insight from the past.Writing on  December , just a few days after his meeting with Walter Macfarlane, Boswell got to thinking about the upheavals caused by unrest and war. He did not much care for the quarrels of Mankind when ided into particular states and nations, he wrote, but he could see that they depended not on facts but on the frailties of humans. ldquoI can see that Great People, those who manage the fates of Kingdoms, he said, ldquoare just such beings as myself.

title: loch-fleet-freezes-over-as-temperatures-drop-across-scotland
story: Yet, as the North Sea froze as it fed into Loch Fleet in Sutherland between Dornoch and Golspie, where the Met Office recorded temperatures of -degCand -degCon respective nights, it betrayed how cold Scotland is right now.To chill the spirits further this Blue Monday, forecasters warn worse is very much on the way.:Cold weather lsquohere to stayrsquo with disruptive snow possible, say forecastersTonightrsquos evening rush hour is already forecast to be a miserable affair, with gales in the north, snow on high ground and torrential rain in the Central Belt.Transport networks, particularly west coast ferries, are likely to be disrupted.Luke Miall, of the Met Office, said: ldquoItrsquos Blue Monday and the temperature maps look pretty blue, too. It has been cold the last few nights and looks to be getting even colder by the middle of this week.ldquoIn higher spots, where snow is lying, we might see -degCor even -degCon Wednesday night.The coldest night the UK has seen so far this winter was the -.degCat Braemar, Aberdeeshire, last week.The term ldquoBlue Monday was dreamed up by Dr Clf Arnall, a psychologist formerly of Cardf University, to portray the most depressing day of the year.He says the third Monday in January is the day when people lose the last glow of the festive period, break New Year resolutions, realise they have put on weight and look out to miserable weatherconditions.Mr Miall added: ldquoThe accompanying frontal system will bring heavy rain and hill snow above  metres .ldquoAnyone driving home after work in the Central Belt will face dficult conditions, with a lot of rain on the ground. There could be blizzards in the north.A forecast of winds gusting to mph has placed many west coast ferry services on notice for delay or cancellation today.Caledonian MacBrayne said the weather could affect sailings from Oban to Coll and Tiree, Fionnphort to Iona, Ullapool to Stornoway, and between Uig, Skye, and Lochmaddy, North Uist.The coldest spell for six years is likely to see  gritters and  snowploughs deployed as the expected five-week big chill from Europe brings an estimated  inches of snow to some areas of Scotland, likely beginning next week.The RAC predicts there will be up to , extra vehicle breakdowns daily across all UK road service providers.Its spokesman Simon Williams said ldquoThis is the biggest test of the countryrsquos winter resilience since the Beast from the East [last February March].ldquoAlmost all gritters will be out. Motorists should pack a blanket, shovel and phone battery charger in case they are needed.Some  gritters in Scotland are digging into a , tonne salt mountain.Network Rail will use  de-icing trains around the UK.

title: one-fifth-of-scottish-businesses-not-ready-for-brexit
story: The Scottish Government-commissioned EY report found Brexit-related uncertainty was a ldquomajor concern for firms north of the Border, affecting competitiveness, profitability and even viability.Companies cited the risk of higher consumer prices ndash particularlyfor food, drink and energy ndashfrom short-term currency risks and from tarfs and border disruptions.:Theresa May set to reveal plan to ditch Irish backstop in bid to win over Brexit deal criticsTwo-thirds of the  participants, which included trade bodies as well as businesses across nine sectors, were not confident the UK would secure a Brexit deal by March.Although  per cent of businesses said they had taken steps to prepare for Brexit, % did ldquonot feel ready for Brexit at all, and only % said they felt fully ready for Brexit.Businesses also raised concerns that Brexit would reduce access to talent at all wage and skill levels,with the food and drink, financial services, le sciences and creative sectors particularly affected.The report states: ldquoTarfs and non-tarf barriers will clearly make it harder for Scottish businesses to trade with the EU, and will likely reduce the volume of trade.ldquoImpacts are likely to be felt quickly, although longer term there may be opportunities to explore alternative international markets and rebuild domestic supply chains.Finance Secretary Derek Mackay said it showed why the UK Government should take a no-deal Brexit off the table immediately.He said: ldquoIt captures the authentic voice of Scottish business and offers further evidence of the severe and disproportionate impacts that a no-deal outcome would have.ldquoMany businesses highlighted the risks to their competitiveness and profitability, some were worried about future viability and a number are already reporting negative impacts on investment, the costs associated with planning for Brexit and recruitment of staff.:Mark Smith: For all our sakes, four facts about the SNP that we can allagree onSeparately, a UK-wide survey of  business leaders by the Institute of Directorsfound a Peoplersquos Vote was the most popular way out of the current impasse.he poll found % of IoD members backeda second referendum, while % would prefer a revised version of Theresa Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, and just % backed a No Deal Brexit.The Federation of Small Businesses also reported almost three in five small firms felt the political uncertainty had become a signicant barrier to growth. It said UK small business confidence had fallen to the lowest level since , particularly in accommodation and food services, retail and manufacturing.FSB national chairman Mike Cherry said: ldquoHow have politicians allowed it to come to this  ldquoTwo and half years on from the Brexit vote and small businesses are looking ahead to Brexit day with no idea of what environment they will be faced with in less than ten weeksrsquo time.

title: glasgows-a-play-a-pie-and-a-pint-15-years-and-500-plays
story: Chamberlain is auditioning later on, and she has  plays to cast. The first of those, a bite-size version of Liz Lochheadrsquos rambunctious Scots version of Molierersquos comedy, Tartuffe, opens in early February. Then there is the small matter of the autumn season, which will feature another twenty plays.Both seasons are landmarks in A Play, A Pie and A Pintrsquos history, founded in  by the late David MacLennan, who had already been at the forefront of popular theatre as co-founder of the original : company before forming Wildcat. As well as it being the initiativersquos fteenth year of operation over thirty seasons, this year will also feature the th play to be produced by A Play, A Pie and A Pint.To celebrate, while the focus of PPP remains on showcasing brand new bite-size dramas, twelve of the forthcoming seasonrsquos productions will form what amounts to a greatest hits set. This shows the range of material which has made its way onto Oran Morrsquos stage in a low-budget, low-risk way light-years away from a prevailing corporate philosophy of big-budget event-based shows.This includes revisiting the debut plays by David Ireland and Denise Mina, as well as favourite shows about comedian Chic Murray, Dusty Springfield and Fe-born darts player, Jocky Wilson. Irelandrsquos play, What The Animals Say, heralded a career which has seen one of his most recent plays, Cyprus Avenue, win numerous awards, while his Traverse Theatre hit, Ulster American, is about to tour to Australia and Ireland. Also revived is Aye, Elvis, Morna Youngrsquos comedy about a female Elvis Presley impersonator.ldquoAfter  years it seems like the right moment to look back, and to celebrate, says Chamberlain.As Fullarton points out, it is also an opportunity to revisit pieces which have all but disappeared from view.ldquoOne of the things about the shows at A Play, A Pie and A Pint is that theyrsquore only on for a week, she says, ldquoso unless the writers and directors can get producers and other theatres interested, they disappear, and there are some cracking plays which deserve the chance of a wider audience, or to be expanded. Therersquos so many wersquod like to bring back, but at the same time keep the new stuff coming up alongside that.Read More: David MacLennan on his lunchtime dreamAs long-time audience members before their involvement in A Play, A Pie and A Pint, while Chamberlain and Fullarton were happy to revive the plays they have done, given the immediacy of PPP, there were some plays that were never going to make the cut.ldquoItrsquos been interesting going back through plays that wersquod only seen many years ago, but which reading them now donrsquot really stand up, and you think, oh, were we just in a really good mood that day when we saw it New works in the spring summer season include The Origins of Ivor Punch, written by Colin MacIntyre and based on the Mull Historical Society singer songwriterrsquos debut novel. There will also be a new piece by Peter McDougall, Last Ferry to Dunoon, while The Mack is Rob Drummondrsquos timely look at the legacy of Charles Rennie Mackintosh in the wake of last yearrsquos second major fire which devastated the Mackintosh-designed Glasgow School of Art.One of the major attractions of the season is Casablanca, Fullartonrsquos own play, a lunchtime version of the iconic film starring Humphrey Bogart. Lest there be any accusations of nepotism, the choice of what plays should be seen again was put to a vote involving Oran Mor regulars, with Casablanca coming out on top.Read More: David MacLennan on his lunchtime dreamldquoWersquore being guided quite a lot by the regular PPP audience, says Chamberlain, ldquoand one of the things wersquove tried to do since we started here is to widen the pool of writers involved. Wersquore putting so much on now that we can maybe afford to get a writer to do another draft of a playitrsquos not quite ready, and we can put that on a bit later.Chamberlain and Fullarton have been at the helm of A Play, A Pie and A Pint since , taking over from producer Susannah Armitage, who had overseen the organisation since MacLennanrsquos passing in . Both come with swathes of experience in theatre and television, with Fullarton combining both in the early s with a TV version of her stage production of Dario Forsquos play, Mistero Buffo, which starred Robbie Coltrane. Chamberlain, meanwhile, co-founded production company The Comedy Unit, responsible for numerous much-loved TV sit-coms.While things have become more streamlined in terms of the day to day running of the company since the early days of PPP, all those involved since have nevertheless retained the sense of low-risk immediacy which MacLennan championed, and despite receiving Creative Scotland funding in a way it might have previously steered clear of, remains a small operation.ldquoOne of the great joys of A Play, A Pie and A Pint for the writers, says Fullarton, ldquois that your play can be on in three months, and it doesnrsquot have to hang around for a year waiting for lots of executive producers to make decisions. Our model is a model that works for actors as well. Itrsquos a three-week gig, so they can fit it in with whatever  theyrsquove got on.At its heart, A play, A Pie and A pintrsquos prevailing spirit echoes the sentiments of the late John McGrath, founder of : and brother-in-law of MacLennan, but with a Play, Pie and a Pint twist.ldquoItrsquos a good night out, says Fullarton, ldquobut at lunchtime.A Play, A Pie and A Pintrsquos spring summer  Celebration Season opens at Oran Mor, Glasgow on February  with Tartuffe by Moliere, adapted by Liz Lochhead. Full details of the season can be found at www.playpiepint.

title: ulva-hundreds-apply-for-a-new-life-on-remote-scottish-island
story: An application processwas established to try and attract those with appropriate skills, such as building, tourism and forestry to the remote island that was subject of a community buyout last year.Once home to over  people in the th century, the island currently has just two properties and five people living there.New ambitious plans will see the population more than double in the next few years with at least six properties added.Last year, a pound.mbid from the Scottish Land Fund and the Macquarie Group in line with a crowdfunding campaign saw the community buy the island.:Islanders halt pound.m Ulva sale with community buyout planThe long term aim is to have  people living on the island.Colin Morrison, thechairman of the North West Mull Community Woodland Company, the body representing residents told the i: ldquoTherersquos been a lot of interest because I think it has captured the imagination.ldquoA lot of people are now aware of what we are trying to do ndash I think we have done reasonably well in getting the word out.ldquoThere is a paucity of housing in rural areas, so therersquos lots of interest because therersquos not much  that comes up.ldquoWe need to be able to show the level of interest before we can apply to renovate and build more houses.ldquoThis survey is about showing and quantying the demand and the interest.:Laird questions SNP government tactics during Ulva buyoutRenovation work on the piers is getting underway shortly, and discussions are ongoing about establishing new woodlands.With applications to live on the island open until the end of January, Mr Morrison is expecting more applications.He said:ldquoSome of the properties we will be renovating will lend themselves to new families.ldquoBut our aim is to get a good balance of people on the island. ldquoIn the next couple of years we hope to get into double figures fairly quickly.ldquoIn the longer, longer run we are looking at up to  people living on the island.ldquoA local primary school already exists just across the water on the mainland at Ulva Ferry.ldquoThe secondary school is in Tobermory on Mull and children will be transported there from the island.

title: snp-mp-angus-macneil-calls-for-party-to-change-strategy-and-for-indyref2-to-come-to-fore

So now it is the referendum with the mandate #Indyref to come to fore... Change in media strategy now  https:t.co VZwFDmygMr MacNeil, who has represented theMr MacNeil, an MP since , also promoted a link to an article by former perjurer and MSP Tommy Sheridan, which called for independence ldquonow, no s, not buts, no maybes.The condemnation of the First Ministerrsquos approach comes after a weekend intervention by Alex Salmond, who told his successor to hurry up with independence.The former First Minister said: ldquoNicola should be concentrating all her energies on the independence agenda when we will never have better circumstance.ldquoAs far as I am concerned Westminsterrsquos Brexit dficulty should be Scotlandrsquos opportunity.ldquoRight now, the Westminster political establishment is at its weakest point in my letime while the national movement is in good heart.ldquoThere is not likely to be a better time to force the issue.:SNP MP tells Nicola Sturgeon people have waited long enough for IndyrefFormer SNP MP George Kerevan also called for a second independence referendum on Monday, warning ldquoScotland will not forgive usthe Brexit crisis was not seized upon.Advocating ldquopushing the independence red button now, he admitted: ldquoI think the majority of the Yes movement is in agony over whatthe best thing to do.Mr Kerevan, a former Marxist who was MP for East Lothian from  to , saidthe UK government continued to deny Holyrood the power for a referendum ldquothen we must march in the streets to demand our democratic rights. When was democracy won without a struggle Writing in the National, he said: ldquoNothing can or will drop in our lap overnight.ldquoBut thatrsquos not the same as waiting for change to come about slowly.ldquoThere are decades where nothing happens politically, and weeks where decades of progress can occur. We are living at such a moment.ldquoLetrsquos not fumble our chance. Scotland will not forgive us.Mr Kerevan also sniped at Andrew Wilson, the author of the SNPrsquos cautious new economic blueprint for independence, for his wary approach to a new plebiscite.The SNP won the  Scottish Parliament elections on a manesto that explicitly stated there should be a fresh vote on independencethere was a material change in circumstances from the  referendum - making clear this should be the caseScotland was removed from the EU against its peoples wishes.Ms Sturgeon has saidshe will make her views known on the possible timing of a second independence referendum in a "matter of weeks".However, the First Minister is facing questions in the wake of Mr Salmonds legal victory against the Scottish Government, after the Court of Session in Edinburgh ruled its handling of sexual misconduct allegations against the former SNP leader to be "unlawful".The allegations - which are strenuously denied by Mr Salmond - have caused a split within the party which he led for  years, with his supporters amplying grassroots calls for Indyref soon.An SNP spokesman said: "The SNP believes that independence for Scotland is the best way to protect our interests and to see our democratic decisions respected."Brexit has brought the failure of the current UK system into sharp focus, with Westminsters shambolic handling of the current situation making the case for independence stronger by the day."Of course, in  Scotland voted by a clear majority to stay in the EU. We continue to fight to protect that status and for the jobs, economic benefits and better living standards that being part of the EU gives us. If theres to be another vote which allow us to remain in Europe, then we should back that opportunity."

title: brexit-theresa-may-scraps-65-fee-for-eu-citizens
story: The Prime Minister confirmed she had scrapped the pound fee millions of EU citizens were going to have to pay as she urgedMPS to back her Brexit deal.:MPs set to start putting forward ious Brexit options ahead of next weeks Commons voteShe told MPs that thepound Settled Status fee for EU citizens will be scrapped after she had listened to concerned EU citizens living in the UK.Speaking in Parliament she said:"The Government will waive the application fee so that there is no financial barrier for any EU nationals who wish to stay."Any paid fees will be reimbursed by those that have applied.A win for @themillion  @theSNP here. Wersquove been campaigning on this since it was announced. Still many, many issues caused by the scrapping of free movement but this is positive news. https:t.co azSeJLmmThe move was welcomed by members of the Opposition.Under previous plans, now scrapped by the PM, residents living in the UK must have lived in the UK for five years and had told they would pay a fee of pound each to retain their status.:Theresa May set to reveal plan to ditch Irish backstop in bid to win over Brexit deal criticsMr Corbyn invited Mrs May to set out which of her Brexit red lines she would rub out to gain consensus.He said: "The Government still appears not to have come to terms with the scale of the defeat in the House of Commons last week."The Prime Minister seems to be going through the motions of accepting the result but in reality is in deep denial."The logic is that the Prime Minister must change her red lines because her current deal is undeliverable."So can she be clear and explicit with the House - which of her red lines is she prepared to move on "Mr Corbyn said: "There is a clear majority in this House to support a deal in principle and to respect the referendum result - but it requires the Prime Minister to face reality and accept her deal has been comprehensively defeated."He asked Mrs May to clary what "concessions" she will seek from the EU over the Irish border backstop, adding: "What makes her think that what she tried to renegotiate in December will succeed in January "This really does feel a bit like Groundhog Day."The PM said she would have further discussions with Northern Irelands DUP and others on their concerns about the Irish backstop.MPs are due to vote on any proposal next Tuesday, after the PMs original plan was defeated last Tuesday by a record-breaking  votes in the House of Commons.

title: herald-diary-mrs-thatcher-the-movie
story: OUR stories suggesting that teenagers dont always think things through reminds a reader in Strathaven: "My we asked our eldest to come home from school during the lunch break and let the dog out. We duly ed home later in the afternoon to discover dog in the garden and back door left wide open. Lesson learned re being more specic with instructions."And another reader says he was pleased when his young son asked one day: "Can I make you a cup of coffee " He was less sure when he then asked: "Do you want it decapitated "Shes toastOUR final week of Burns Supper stories as entertainer Andy Cameron recalls: "Many years ago at a Burns Supper in an Ayrshire miners club the chairman announced after the loyal toast, The Queen is drunk, you may now smoke, and he may also be the chap who informed the audience that the haggis was tonight piped in by Pipe Major Robert McGillycuddy, and tomorrow will be piped out by Armitage Shanks."Got the pictureWE mentioned the number of locals who were watching the Auchinleck Talbot v Ayr United Scottish Cup tie from their bedroom windows overlooking the ground even though it was live on BBC Scotland.
